SUMMARY: Glycine cleavage A, GcvA, is a repressor of glycine cleavage enzyme system, which is a secondary pathway for production of C1 units [8188587]. It is negatively autoregulated, and it coordinately activates transcription of a small-RNA divergent gene [7665470, 10972807]. In absence of glycine and presence of GcvR, GcvA represses operons involved in glycine cleavage system [7665470, 10972807, 11495998]. GcvR is an accessory protein that binds directly to GcvA, bending DNA to form a repression complex (GcvA/GcvR) in regulatory region of gcvT operon [11495998]. Glycine binds directly to GcvR to disrupt or block association of GcvA/GcvR complex, whereas purines appear to promote formation of repression complex through an unknown mechanism [12101307, 11495998]. GcvA also activates transcription of gcv genes, via interaction with α or σ subunits of RNA polymerase [15621456]. This transcriptional dual regulator, which belongs to LysR-family [8188587] has two domains: amino-terminal domain, which appears to be involved in transcription activation and in DNA binding through its helix-turn-helix subdomain, and carboxy-terminal domain, involved in GcvR interaction [9733689, 11495998]. GcvA binding sites do not show a clear conservation in ir sequences except for a short 5'-CTAAT-3' region [7665470].
